Description: The hot air balloon was invented.
The New York Stock and Exchange Board is founded.
First smallpox vaccine is administered.
Napoleon comes to power in France.
Great Britian and Ireland unify to form United Kingdom
World population hits 1 billion
Beethoven preforms his Fifth Symphony
Jane Austen publishes Pride and Prejudice
Argentina gains independence
The bicycle is invented
Antartica is discovered
Mexico gains independece
Mexico won its independence from Spain, and San Diego became part of the Mexican territory of Alta California.
Samuel Morey patents the internal combustion engine
British Empire bans slavery
Oliver Twist is published by Charles Dickens
Anaesthesia is used in a medical procedure for the first time.
The Mexican-American war began. Under the terms of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo in 1848, the U.S. and gained control over the area of San Diego
Seneca Falls Convention marks the first woman's rights convention in the United States
California is granted statehood by the United States of America.
City of San Diego Incorporation
"New San Diego is born"
Fredrick Douglas delivers his speech "The Meaning of July Fourth for the Negro" in Rochester, New York.
San Diego County Board of Supervisors holds its first meeting

Warner’s Pass (San Pasqual) road is declared a public road by the San Diego County Board of Supervisors, serving as a main road between San Diego and the Colorado River until 1868, when shorter routes to the south, leading through the pass at Jacumba, began to be used by stagecoaches.

Warner’s Pass (San Pasqual) road is declared a public road by the San Diego County Board of Supervisors, serving as a main road between San Diego and the Colorado River until 1868, when shorter routes to the south, leading through the pass at Jacumba, began to be used by stagecoaches.

Whaley House, built by Thomas Whaley, is the oldest brick structure in southern California. In addition to being the home of the Whaley family, it served variously as granary, store, court-house, and school and as the town’s first theater.

James Birch establishes the “Jackass” mail route between San Diego and San Antonio; passengers must traverse the Oriflamme Canyon and Colorado Desert on muleback. Stage driver James E. Mason brings first overland mail to town and decides to settle here.

James Birch establishes the “Jackass” mail route between San Diego and San Antonio; passengers must traverse the Oriflamme Canyon and Colorado Desert on muleback. Stage driver James E. Mason brings first overland mail to town and decides to settle here.
Charles Darwin publishes On The Origin Of Species.
The iron ship Star of India, built on the Isle of Man in 1863, is towed to San Diego but remains in disrepair for the next 30 years.
American Civil War Ends
Slavery abloished in the United States
Kimball brothers buy 26,400 acres of Rancho de la Nacion and lay out National City.
Ephraim Morse presents a resolution to the Board of Trustees of San Diego that land be set aside for a city park. Morse, Thomas Bush and Alonzo Horton select the land now known as Balboa Park.
Albert Seeley purchases the run-down Bandini Adobe in Old Town and spends six months in renovation of the old home to create the Cosmopolitan Hotel, building the Seeley Stables next door.

Alonzo Horton completes a wharf at the end of 5th Avenue, at a cost of about $45,000. On March 24, Horton sells $5,500 worth of commercial and residential lots in one day. His new town begins to boom.

Horton Hall opens around Christmas 1869. This two-story brick building on the southeast corner of Sixth and F streets has shops downstairs and a meeting hall with 400 seats upstairs, serving as downtown’s first public theater.
Suez Canal is complete.
San Diego becomes the first city west of the Mississippi to set aside land for an urban park. This 1440 acre tract becomes the site for City Park, now Balboa Park.
first major hotel was built

first bank in the San Diego: the Bank of San Diego; followed by the Commercial Bank of San Diego in 1872. The tow merged in the Consolidated Bank of San Diego in 1879. (https://sandiegohistory.org/archives/books/smythe/part6-8/)
The feudal system is dismantled in Japan
Blue jeans are invented.
Thomas Scott of Pennsylvania Railroad sets off brief railroad boom with start of construction of Texas & Pacific Railroad from San Diego east
President Ulysses S. Grant signed an Executive Order creating tribal reservations for Santa Ysabel, Pala, Sycuan, La Jolla, Rincon, and Capitan Grande.
Asaph Hall discovers the moons of Mars
Lieutenant Reade of the U.S. Weather Bureau gives first public demonstration of the telephone in San Diego County.
First commercial telephone exchange.
Thomas Edison invents the light bulb.
Frank Kimball of National City founds the San Diego County Fair.
California Southern started to build San Diego’s first outside rail connection. a line from National City to Colton
San Diego Telephone Company begins operation
Carlsbad Mineral Water was discovered
The volcano Krakatoa erupts, it's the largest eruption in modern history.
John Montgomery makes world’s first “controlled flight” in a “heavier than air” craft, flying 600 feet in a glider at Otay Mesa. Montgomery is later killed in a 1911 glider crash.
Construction of Hotel del Coronado begins in 1886
Transcontinental railroad reaches San Diego. The first train of the California Southern departs from San Diego on November 15 and on November 21 the first train arrives from the east.

to 1890 - saw the organization and construction of no fewer than five independent railroad lines: the Central California; the National City & Otay; the San Diego, Old Town & Pacific Beach; the Coronado; and the San Diego, Cuyamaca and Eastern. In addition, Santa Fe built a new link from Oceanside to Orange County — the “Surf Line,” and San Diego’s first horsedrawn trolleys began to ply the city’s streets.
Transcontinental railroad reaches San Diego.
Karl Benz sells the first commercial automobile.
First electric street lights installed in San Diego.
Construction begins on Cuyamaca Dam and a wooden flume 35 miles long to bring water to San Diego, completed in 1888.
San Diego Street Car Company Begins Service
Public Transportation Begins
National City Incorporation
The first electric motor makes test run on new tracks up Broadway to Kettner and on to Old Town
Escondido Incorporation
Oceanside Incorporation

Sweetwater Dam, a major engineering feat and San Diego County’s first major dam, is completed by the Kimball Brothers Water Company, supplying water for National City and Chula Vista. Speeches and music mark the celebration on April 19. The dam measures 396 feet in length and 12 feet wide at the top, 75 feet in length and 46 feet wide at the base. Original plans for building the dam 60 feet in height were changed to 98 feet, increasing capacity of the reservoir fivefold.
San Diego’s 1880s real estate boom ends. By the end of the decade the population has dropped from 40,000 to 16,000.
Vincent van Gogh paints Starry Night
Coronado Incorporation
Completion of the Tran-Siberian Railroad
Fisher Opera House opens on Fourth Street between B and C, an opulent but practical house seating 1400 in the best theater on the West Coast.
Basketball is invented.
Wall Street panic leads to lengthy depression.

Bad times encourage Alonzo Horton to sell his half-block Horton Plaza park to the city for $10,000, stipulating that it must remain a park forever. Under the agreement, the city agrees to pay Horton $100 a month with no interest and no down payment. In the event of Horton’s death, the city would acquire the property outright. The city fathers underestimate Horton’s endurance. In April 1903, 89-year-old Horton cashes the final payment for a total of $16,000. Today Horton’s park fronts Horton Plaza and has been renamed Horton Plaza Park.
The Olympic Games are revived in Athens
SDSU Opens

Army establishes Fort Rosecrans, named after General Rosecrans, an 1842 graduate of the US Military Academy. It remains an Army base until transfer to the Navy in 1959 for the purpose of building a submarine base on Ballast Point.
By decision of the U.S. Supreme Court, Indian inhabitants of Cupa, San Felipe and nearby villages around Warner Springs are evicted and removed to lands near the Pala Reservation.
The first heavier-than-air controlled flight is preformed by the Wright Brothers

San Diego County Hospital opens at the north end of Front Street on mesa overlooking Mission Valley. Total cost is about $60,000.The 90 patients residing in the previous county medical institution, the County Poor Farm in Mission Valley, are transferred up the hill on May 15th.
Development of Presidio Park begins; Marston, Spreckels, Scripps and other investors begin buying Presidio property to preserve as a park.
Development of Presidio Park begins; Marston, Spreckels, Scripps and other investors begin buying Presidio property to preserve as a park.
Great White Fleet
Great White Fleet
Spreckels forces a ballot initiative
Miramar Air show hold inaugural show
Chula Vista Incorporation
Xinhai Revolution in China overthrows the Qing Dynasty, the last imperial dynasty in China.
Glenn Hammond Curtiss makes world’s first successful seaplane flight from waters off Spanish Bight, a mile-ling stretch between North Island and Coronado (now filled in).
Spruce Street’s suspension bridge, between Front and Brant, was built to give residents access to the streetcars running along Fourth.
Spreckels Theatre opens with 1915 seats (the year of the coming Exposition). It is the first modern commercial playhouse west of the Mississippi.
La Mesa Incorporation
El Cajon Incorporation
William Kettner (1864-1930) is elected to the U.S. House of Representatives from California 11th District, 1913-1921
Navy establishes a base on North Island, with three airplanes and three fliers. On Thanksgiving Day, 1912, the Army Signal Corps establishes Rockwell Field with an aviation school on North Island.

Spruce Street’s suspension bridge, between Front and Brant, was built to give residents access to the streetcars running along Fourth. The only suspension bridge still standing in the city was designed by Edwin M. Capps, City Engineer and later Mayor of San Diego.
Broadway Pier is constructed with a $1.7 million bond issued by the city.
Broadway Pier is constructed
Santa Fe Depot construction begins June 15, replacing the earlier Grand Union Depot.
Cabrillo Bridge opens on April 12, 1914. The first car is driven across with Franklin D. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, G. Aubrey Davidson, and Mayor Charles F. O’Neall as passengers.
San Diego hosts the Panama-California Exposition
The Armenian Genocide in the Ottoman Empire
The New Santa Fe Depot
Panama-California Exposition
Dr. Harry Wegeforth brings the San Diego Zoo into being when animals imported for the 1915 Panama-California Exposition are quarantined and not allowed to leave.
Army Camp Kearny (later MCAS Miramar) and Marine Corps Camp Mathews (later UCSD)
U.S. Navy opens the most powerful radio station in the Western Hemisphere at Chollas Heights.

World War I prompts San Diego military buildup. Camp Kearny is established, named in honor of Gen. Stephen Kearny who led the Army of the West to San Diego in 1846. It costs $4.5 million to build and is closed in 1920.
U.S. Marine Base and Naval Hospital approved; government purchases North Island, its Rockwell Field shared by the Army and Navy until 1939.
WWI ends.
Commander Navy Southwest established (formerly known as Naval Base San Diego / Eleventh Naval District)

San Diego & Arizona Railroad is finally completed. John D. Spreckels drives the final golden spike. A thousand spectators observe. After thirteen years of labor (and $17,000,000) San Diego achieves a direct link with the East.
Many California Natives join together to challenge federal powers through the Mission Indian Federation
San Diego’s Pacific Marine Construction company launches two concrete ships, the Cuyamaca and the San Pasqual. Begun during WWI but completed after the war ended, both ships serve as oil tankers.
Russia invades Georgia. Beginning the Soviet Union.
Naval Training Center San Diego (Marine Corps Recruit Depot)
Naval Hospital Balboa Park is commissioned on 22 August with initial capacity of 250 beds.
US Navy Destroyer Base (Naval Base San Diego)
First motor bus the #1 from Chula Vista to National City
Ellen Browning Scripps made a $250,000 contribution to establish the forty-four-bed Scripps Hospital in La Jolla
Vladamir Lenin dies, leading to a power struggle between Trotsky and Stalin.
First US Aircraft Carrier (USS Langley) operates out of North Island
Ellen Browning Scripps funds 44 bed hospital
Mission Beach Amusement Center (now Belmont Park) opens.
US Naval Hospital
The Fine Arts Gallery in Balboa Park, designed by William Templeton Johnson and funded by Appleton Bridges, is dedicated & opens to the public. It is now the San Diego Museum of Art.
El Cortez Hotel opens as San Diego’s “finest” furnished apartment-hotel.

Charles Lindbergh departs from Rockwell field, North Island, Coronado, in the Spirit of St. Louis, a custom M-1 monoplane built in San Diego by Ryan Airlines. Lindbergh completes his historic solo nonstop flight from New York to Paris May 20-21.
San Diego Municipal Airport – Lindbergh Field was dedicated
California Natives challenge past US actions and obtain a partial settlement for some claims
Penicillin is discovered.
San Diego International Airport opened on August 16, 1928.
FIFA World Cup is held for the first time.
At San Diego International Airport, the San Diego-Los Angeles airmail route was initiated on June 1. At 5 p.m. sharp, the first airmail plane left the only building at the airport.

The people of the Capitan Grande reservation that was established in 1875 were moved to two different ranches in 1932 after the City of San Diego acquired 7,000 acres of land for the El Capitan Reservoir..
Reuben H. Fleet moves Consolidated Aircraft (which becomes Convair) from Buffalo, New York to San Diego. Fleet had organized the first U.S. Air Mail Service in 1918.
Convair moves to San Diego
The Natural History Museum opens in Balboa Park
the first hospital in Escondido opened under the name Escondido Community Hospital
Prohibition in the United States is abolished.
The eleventh district of the California Division of Highways was created
The Old Globe Theatre opens in Balboa Park

Consolidated Aircraft opens first plant along Pacific Highway to build 50 P-30 pursuit planes for Army. First PBY-1 is launched on test flight on San Diego bay in 1936 – Consair employment rises from 900 in 1935 to 3700.
Ruben Fleet Consilidated Aircraft
Del Mar turf Club (del mar racetrack) opens
US Coast Guard Air Station

Richard Archbold makes first transcontinental flight from San Diego to New York City in a seaplane built by Consair. The following year the Archbold expedition sets off from San Diego on a global survey of potential oceanic and continental air routes (pilots Steve Barinka, Russell Rogers). It arrives back in San Diego on July 6, 1939 as the first around-the-world seaplane flight at the equator.
San Diego Civic Center opens
Nazi's invade Poland, marking the beginning of WWII.
National War Emergency Declared
Naval Air Station, Miramar develops on the site of Camp Kearny.
Goodrich Corp Aerostructures Systems established in San Diego
National war emergency declared
American Indians volunteer in large numbers for military service
Marine Base Camp Elliott
Japans bombs Pearl Harbor, involving the United States in WWII
San Diego Naval Air Station begins training pilots for U.S. Air Force (a total of 31,400 during World War II).
Construction begins on Linda Vista defense housing project. The biggest construction job in SD’s history – McNeil and Zoss contract to build 3000 units in 300 days for $9,070,000.
Navy acquires Rancho Santa Margarita for Camp Pendleton Marine base on 126,000 acres north of Oceanside.

San Diego International Airport: The U.S. Army Air Corps took over the airport in 1942, and Army engineers improved the existing runways to accommodate the heavy bombers churned out by San Diego's aircraft manufacturers during World War II.
Navy begins emergency construction of aqueduct to bring Colorado River water to San Diego.
San Diego County Water Authority created
By the end of WWII, the Naval Hospital grows to 241 buildings with a bed capacity of 10,499.
Senate ratifies a treaty giving a portion of Colorado River water to Mexico.
San Diego voters approve 2 million dollar bond issue to begin development of Mission Bay.
Navy Electronics Laboratory Established (NAVWAR?)
World War II ends. San Diego soon experiences recession.
San Diego assumes responsibility to finance completion of San Diego Aqueduct. Voters approve $2 million water bonds and annexation of County Water Authority to Metropolitan Water District
Submarine Group San Diego (Naval Base Point Loma)
The sound barrier is broken by a human flown aircraft.
San Diego Water Authority with Navy and U.S. Bureau of Reclamation to construct the first two pipelines linking San Diego County and the Colorado River Aqueduct
OECD and WHO are established.
Palomar Observatory opens in June. Construction on the 200-inch mirror had begun in 1934.
Pacific Southwest Airlines established its headquarters in San Diego and started service at Lindbergh Field
Construction of what will become the first college of USD begins
Mao comes to power in the People's Republic of China.
Palomar Memorial Hospital opened with a capacity of 37 beds
Cubic Inc established in San Diego
San Diego Open (now Farmers Insurance Open) begins annual golf tournament
Carlsbad Incorporation
Miramar Naval Air Station
The Naval hospital treats about 90,000 patients during the Korean conflict
The first ascent of Mt. Everst is achieved.
WD-40 invented in a small lab in San Diego
City Charter amendment was to give the City Council the authority to build or approve the construction of any roads in parks.
San Diego City Council offers the University of California, at no cost, “city-owned land for students who are desirous of entering into the professional field of engineering.”
Grossmont Hospital opens
San Diego City Council offers the University of California, at no cost, “city-owned land for students who are desirous of entering into the professional field of engineering.”
San Diego City Council offers 300-acre gift of Torrey Pines land to General Atomic
General Atomics
San Diego City Council gifts land
Imperial Beach Incorporation
Sharp performs San Diego's first cardiac catheterization, a procedure that enables cardiologists to see inside the heart and major arteries.
Russian's launch Sputnik 1
First test of USAF Atlas A missile is launched, built in San Diego by Convair. Fort Rosecrans transferred to US Navy.
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs San Diego's first open-heart surgery.

City Council approves zone change to allow May Department Stores Company to build shopping center in Mission Valley. (https://sandiegohistory.org/archives/books/citydream/chronology/). The Mall (1st in the county) was completed in 1961.
Interstate Highway 8 opens in February, following ancient Indian trails through Mission Valley.
land gifted for the UCSD campus
Del Mar Incorporation
General Dynamics established in San DIego
San Diego State College becomes a member of the California State University system.

On November 18, the University of California, San Diego is officially established and students enroll. The campus is realized through state appropriations, a donation from General Dynamics and a gift from the city of 63 acres of pueblo land northeast of Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
SDSU establishes KPBS-FM educational radio station
in a special referendum, the citizens of San Diego overwhelmingly voted support for the gift of these pueblo lands to the Salk Institute
State approves proposition to deliver water from northern California as far south as San Diego.
The Year of Africa, 17 African nations gain independence.
San Diego International Airport: United Airlines became the first airline to offer pure jet service in September 1960
American Football League Chargers open first season at Balboa Stadium.
Mission Valley Shopping Center opens.
Sharp HealthCare installs the first electronic pacemaker west of St. Louis.
Mission Valley Shopping Center opens.
Grossmont Shopping Center opens.
The first major long-term rehabilitation center specializing in care for patients with spinal cord, stroke and brain injuries opens at Sharp Memorial Hospital.
San Diego Unified Port District created
John F. Kennedy give commencement speech at San Diego State College (later SDSU)
Construction of the new, 600-bed County Hospital is completed in July at a cost of $11.5 million for building and equipment.(UCSD)
San Marcos Incorporation
Vista Incorporation
MLK delivers "I Have A Dream" speech
San Diego Unified Port District: Tenth Ave. Marine Terminal Bulkloading Facility Completed
Seaworld opens
University of California at San Diego opens 1,000-acre La Jolla campus
The new 240-bed Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla opens on Genesee Avenue.
City Administration Building opens downtown at Community Concourse.

The end of the Bracero program (the official temporary worker arrangement started in 1942) prompts a flow of migrant workers back to Mexico. The Mexican government establishes an industrialization program to create job opportunities for those workers. Maquiladoras, or “assembly plants,” are built in border towns to employ Mexican labor who will assemble goods for the U.S. market. The maquiladora industry increases interdependance between the countries.
UC San Diego opens La Jolla campus
Maxwell Technologies Inc established in San Diego
Mexico authorizes maquiladora factories, Mexican assembly or manufacturing operations that can be wholly or partially owned and managed by non-Mexican companies.
Bob Breitbard completes Sports Arena in Midway area.
UC San Diego begins operating “University Hospital” as its primary clinical teaching facility. Second College is renamed after conservationist and author, John Muir.
Local governments create the Comprehensive Planning Organization (CPO) as a long-range planning department within the San Diego County government under a state authorized joint powers agreement.
$27 million San Diego Stadium opens in Mission Valley as home to the San Diego Chargers and the San Diego State University Aztecs football team, and expanded to the San Diego Padres in 1969.
UC San Diego Health announces plans to open the region’s first kidney transplant unit.
The minor-league San Diego Padres become a Major League Baseball team
A pioneering family planning clinic is opened, offering contraception information and all types of birth control options.(UCSD)
San Diego’s first organ transplant, a kidney transplant, is performed on a 32-year-old former aircraft worker with a kidney donated by his older brother. (UCSD)
Committee of 100 leads successful bond drive for first historic reconstruction in Balboa Park (Casa del Prado completed 1971).
San Diego Unified Port District: Cargo handling begins at National City Marine Terminal
San Diego–Coronado Bay Bridge opens
Fashion Valley Mall opens.
Apollo 11 lands a man on the moon for the first time.
Coronado Bridge Opens
San Diego–Coronado Bay Bridge opens
San Diego City Council dedicates 6,000 acre La Jolla Underwater Park
Comic-Con
Mexican-American community campaigns for creation of Chicano Park beneath San Diego-Coronado Bay Bridge.
Port of San Diego: First Port cruise ship call out of San Diego
Governor designates CPO as the Metropolitan Planning Organization to assure areawide coordination and to serve as the technical and informational resource for local governments.
Mayor and council members indicted in Yellow Cab scandal.
Bazaar del Mundo opens shop in Old Town featuring specialty Latin America gifts and items.
State further designates CPO as the Regional Transportation Planning Agency; Airport Land Use Commission; and Areawide Clearinghouse for federal/state grant reviews.
Kyocera established in San Diego
Sharp Memorial Hospital features San Diego's first fully computerized laboratory reporting system.

Sharp introduces San Diego's first patient representative program with a full-time staff member. The representative acts as an advocate for patients in meeting their needs and concerns during hospitalization.
The Veterans administration opens a $48 million hospital adjacent to UCSD Hospital.
Shopping Center opens in El Cajon later to be named Parkway Plaza

Southern California Tribal Chairmen's Association (SCTCA) is established. It is a nonprofit composed of 20 federally recognized Indian tribes in Southern California with goals to serve the health welfare cultural and economic needs of tribal members.
Local governments establish CPO as an independent Joint Powers Agency.

San Diego is chosen as the site of Republican National Convention; in a last-minute about-face, Republicans announce plans to move convention site to Miami Beach. The loss of the convention prompted Mayor Pete Wilson to declare San Diego “America’s Finest City”.
Reuben H. Fleet Space Theater opens to the public in Balboa Park.
Neurologists successfully treat refractory epilepsy patients with a special brain surgery that removes small sections of the brain where seizures occur.(UCSD)
Pink Floyd releases "Dark Side of the Moon"
City rezones Torey Mesa pueblo lands
Sharp HealthCare introduces the first driver-education program for disabled individuals in San Diego.
Jamul Indian Village finally receives federal trust status. Other landless California tribes such as the San Luis Rey Band of Mission Indians continue to seek federal recognition.
CPO develops & adopts first ever comprehensive Regional Transportation Plan.
Mayor Pete Wilson launches plans for a dramatic redevelopment of downtown San Diego, creating Centre City Development Corporation.
Sharp debuts San Diego's first hospital-based alcohol and drug treatment program.
· San Diego's first total body Computerized Tomography (CT) scanner to provide a three-dimensional detailed image of internal organs.
The Regional Trauma Center opens.(UCSD)
The UC San Diego Outpatient Center in Hillcrest is completed.
San Diego Hospice is founded.
Pomerado Hospital opened as the District’s second hospital, which today is a 107-bed acute-care facility.
University Towne Centre shopping mall opens near UCSD.
Lemon Grove Incorporation
Star Wars becomes the highest grossing movie of all time.
San Diego Transit carries over 30 million passengers on 44 routes with a fleet of 350 buses and a flat-rate fare of $0.35.

San Diego's first biotechnology company, Hybritech, is co-founded by UC San Diego assistant professor Ivor Royston and his research assistant Howard Birndorf. Since then, faculty, staff and alumni have created more than 640 companies, including many local biotech firms.

The Local Technical Assistance (LTA) program is started for member governments. CPO helps establish the Automated Regional Justice Information System (ARJIS). CPO is jointly designated with County government to implement federal & state Clean Air Acts.
California voters approve Proposition 13 (limits to property tax), throwing local municipal finances into chaos.
Artificial Insulin is invented.
The Life Flight helicopter-ambulance program is inaugurated.
MTDB's Board Member Maureen O'Connor negotiates purchase of SD&AE Railway For $18.1 million. Annual ridership in this decade improves from 18 million to 35 million.
Gaming begins to grow in importance to some of the local Indian Nations.
Poway Incorporation
Santee Incorporation
CPO renames itself as the San Diego Association of Governments (SANDAG).
SANDAG and Armed Forces MOA (revised in 1986)
The San Diego Trolley, first line in the city’s new light-rail transit system, is dedicated.
Plaza Bonita shopping center opens in National City.
San Diego Trolley begins service to border. San Diego Trolley inaugural run takes place between U.S. International Border and Downtown San Diego.
San Diego Trolley begins service to border! San Diego Trolley inaugural run takes place on 15.9 "South Line" between U.S. International Border and Downtown San Diego.
many employers began to offer employees preferred provider organizations (PPOs) and HMO plans other than Kaiser
Pete Wilson elected to U.S. Senate, first U.S. senator from San Diego.
Michael Jackson releases Thriller album
Research Consortium
Sharp creates the first hospital-based program designed for the young children of alcoholics and other chemically dependent parents at Sharp Vista Pacifica
Roger Hedgecock elected mayor (resigns in 1985 over campaign fund-raising scandal).
ARPANET (later "internet") is created.
Otay Mesa Land Port of Entry opened to traffic, providing additional capacity to the border.
Otay Mesa Land Port of Entry (POE) opened
UC San Diego is designated one of the first five national Alzheimer’s disease research centers by the National Institute on Aging.
Horton Plaza shopping center opens
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs the first implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD)
Horton Plaza shopping center opens as $140 million cornerstone of downtown redevelopment.
Axelgaard Manufacturing Co. Ltd established in San Diego
Otay Mesa POE opens to bidirectional passenger and northbound commercial traffic. Southbound commercial processing continues at San Ysidro (Virginia Ave.)
East Line
UC San Diego Connect
The San Diego Supercomputer Center opens at the University of California, San Diego
North County Fair shopping center opens in Escondido.
Encinitas Incorporation
Solana Beach Incorporation
Maureen O’Connor is elected as San Diego’s first woman mayor
Challenger and Chernobyl disasters.
The San Diego Supercomputer Center opens at the University of California, San Diego, providing the national research community with access to the highest-performance computers available.​
ViaSat Inc established in San Diego
UC San Diego Alumnus Susumu Tonegawa wins the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of the genetic mechanism that produces antibody diversity.

California v. Cabazon Band of Mission Indians is passed by the US Supreme Court. It held that Indian Nations have the right to establish gaming standards for any activities that are legal in the State.
World population reaches 5 billion
Life Technologies Corp established in San DIego
San Diego hosts its first Super Bowl
Federal Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (IGRA) passes after a long legal battle that went through the US Supreme Court. This law provides framing for national regulation of Native American gaming.
TransNet approved
TransNet approved
Del Mar Highland Town Center opens
The fall of the Berlin Wall
California State University, San Marcos, opens
Sharp HealthCare performs its first kidney transplant on July 19, 1990, at Sharp Memorial Hospital.
Scripps Green Hospital starts San Diego’s first successful liver transplant program.
Most of the tribes had developed or had agreements to develop gaming facilities as a means of economic development

Indian gaming becomes a key part of the San Diego regional economy. The Barona, Campo, Jamul Indian Village, Pala, Pauma and Yulma, San Pasqual, Sycuan, and Viejas reservations all have open gaming facilities. La Posta and Santa Ysabel have closed gaming facilities.
Tribal EPA officers are established throughout the region
Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act is passed to provide avenue for the repatriation of human remains and cultural items
SANDAG helps start the San Dieguito River Valley Park Joint Powers Authority.
Former San Diego Mayor Pete Wilson is elected Governor of California, the state’s first governor from San Diego.
San DIego Unified Port District: National City Marine Terminal receives first vehicle imports
Bayside Line
Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego opens the Stephen Birch Aquarium and Museum on September 16, 1992.
Sharp performs its first heart-lung transplant surgery.
California Public Employees Retirement System (CalPERS) took an assertive bargaining stance with health plans on behalf of its one million state and local government enrollees
Native American Historic Protection Act is passed and provides avenues for Native American nations to protect their historical cultural lands

State designates SANDAG as the San Diego-Coronado Bridge Toll Authority. SANDAG helps form a five-county rail coalition, and purchases rail right-of-way from Santa Fe Railway for the COASTER, and the Oceanside to Escondido SPRINTER rail commuter services.
North Line
Susan Golding elected Mayor of City of San DIego
General Atomics Aeronautical Systems Inc established in San DIego
Shoreline Preservation Strategy

North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) was enacted. Side agreements result in the creation of the North American Development Bank (NADB) and the Border Environmental Cooperation Commission (BECC) spurring high levels of border related investment.

North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) was enacted. Side agreements result in the creation of the North American Development Bank (NADB) and the Border Environmental Cooperation Commission (BECC) spurring high levels of border related investment.

Operation Gatekeeper was enacted leading to the construction of fence refortifications along the border and increasing the budget for U.S. Border Patrol. Over the next few years the number of officers and budget for BorderPatrol would double.

HMOs accounted for about half of 2.1 million insured enrollees, including two-thirds of employment-based health insurance enrollees, 43 percent of Medicare enrollees, and about 17 percent of Medi-Cal enrollees

The San Diego County Water Authority joins SANDAG as an advisory member. SANDAG plays a major role in bringing together, and most importantly, holding together, all participants in the San Diego County Investment Fund.
General dynamics closes Convair division in SD
Virginia Ave border crossing (which was located in where the current PedWest facility is) closes for commercial operations and all is consolidated at the Otay Mesa POE
COASTER service began
Nearshore Habitat Inventory
UC San Diego Health surgeons successfully separate conjoined twins, born attached at the chest and abdomen. The separated twins are discharged nine days later.
San Diego hosts Republican National Convention, first national political convention in San Diego history.
Dolly the sheep becomes the first successful cloned mammal.
SANDAG creates the Committee on Binational Regional Opportunities (COBRO) to help coordinate on increasingly dynamic border issues
Secure Electronic Network for Travelers Rapid Inspection (SENTRI) lane opened at Otay Mesa LPOE (1 lane), which was the first of it's kind to be implemented in the U.S.
SANDAG starts the I-15 FasTrak Program to improve traffic flow, and expand bus and rideshare services in the corridor.
Regional Beach Monitoring Program established
San Diego Regional Clean Cities Coalition

SANDAG and COBRO began hosting Annual Binational Events to bring together stakeholders from both sides of the border to seek out solutions and identify opportunities around a wide range of topics ranging from water and energy supply,crossborder climate change to border wait times and homeland security issues.
South County - Multiple Species Conservation Program
Coors Amphitheatre opens in Chula Vista
Super Bowl held in (renamed) Qualcomm Stadium
Rock n’ Roll Marathon hold inaugural marathon
Scripps Center for Women’s Health, which includes 12 state-of-the-art birthing suites, opens at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla.
Voters approve convention center expansion, downtown Padres ballpark, $1.5 billion city school bonds.
Google is founded.
Navy embarked on a new era of Shore Management
Voters approve convention center expansion, downtown Padres ballpark, $1.5 billion city school bonds.
San Diego International Airport: Port expands San Diego Airport Terminal 2
Mission Valley Line
Legoland California opens in Carlsbad.
Scripps Health, Scripps Clinic and The Scripps Research Institute join forces to create the Scripps Cancer Center integrating basic research, clinical research, cancer care and community outreach.
Mexico surpassed Japan to become California’s top export trade market. Mexico was second in total trade with the U.S., but is now third because China surpassed it as of 2006
Multiple Species Conservation Plan and Multiple Habitat Conservation Plans are passed for many cities in the region. Tribal nations feel frustration at the lack of inclusion of tribal boundaries
Disaster Mitigation Act of 2000 is passed. This requires state, local, and Indian tribal governments to coordinate planning and implementation efforts
MTDB and NCTD join SANDAG as advisory members, and SANDAG joins the Joint Committee on Regional Transit.
Dick Murphy elected Mayor of City of San Diego

Connecting roadway to the Otay Mesa POE (then Otay Mesa Road) is designated as an expressway was widened to six lanes in 2000. Before, it had 50 percent more traffic than it was designed to handleit was considered by the San Diego Union-Tribune as "California's busiest trade route with Mexico".
SENTRI lane implemented at the San Ysidro POE
SANDAG adopts the $29 billion, 20-year Regional Transportation Plan to reduce traffic congestion and limit urban sprawl.
Business and Education partnerships
Las Americas Premium Outlets opens in San Ysidro
The County Tribal Liaison Program was established
World Trade Center attack.
C-TPAT secure-cargo shipping program launched

SANDAG forms the Borders Policy Committee, which was reaffirmed in 2003 by law SB 1703, with Imperial County as a regular member, and representatives from neighboring Orange and Riverside Counties and Mexico. Tribal Governments, through the Southern California Tribal Chairmen’s Association, became Advisory Members of Borders, and later of the Board of Directors and other PACs.
Terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001 change the dynamics of border crossings around the country. Protective measures of the nation's borders begin scaling up.
C-TPAT secure-cargo shipping program launched
Regional Beach Sand Project
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs the first heart-kidney transplant in San Diego.
Scripps opens Mercy Gardens to house AIDS/HIV patients on the campus of Scripps Mercy Hospital
SANDAG hold policy development Board meeting with tribal nations
The Native American Tribal Liaison Program was established to work with regional tribes.
SANDAG drafts a $42 billion, 30-year Regional Transportation Plan seeking to make public transit competitive with solo drivers during rush hours.
The Euro enters circulation

Under the Homeland Security Act (2002) the federal government establishes the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Security, compliance and facilitation of international travel and trade is consolidated under Customs and Border Protection (U.S. CBP).

DHS implements heightened security measures, shifting from mostly randomized screenings for cars and people to comprehensive checks for nearly all crossers. Other screenings included the collection of fingerprints and biometric data (i.e. USVISIT program). The level of comprehensive checks decreased over time as CBP began to experience capacity/resource issues.
State of the Coast Report - Regional Beach Monitoring Program
Super Bowl 37 held at Qualcomm Stadium

The County of San Diego conducts a Traffic Impact Assessment related to tribal developments. The report identifies improvement opporunities on SR 76, 67, 94 as they are heavily trafficked roads for those heading to gaming facilities.
Caltrans and SANDAG create the first regional map that includes tribal nations

With the passage of state law (SB 1703), SANDAG becomes the consolidated regional agency on January 1. Transit planning, programming, project development, and construction will be consolidated into the regional agency during the next 13 months. Imperial County joins SANDAG as an advisory Board member.
Imperial County joins SANDAG as an advisory Board member.
North Country - Multiple Habitat Conservation Program
Series 10: 2030 Regional Growth Forecast - Historical Projection
Petco Park Opens
USS Midway opened as a museum to the public
Carlsbad Premium Outlets opens name-brand and designer outlet shopping center.
SANDAG creates the Tribal Liaison Program
Transnet Extension Ordinance and Expenditure Plan approved by the voters. This provides funding for transportation and environmental efforts
The Automated Regional Justice System (ARJIS) is consolidated into SANDAG.
San Diegan’s vote to Continue the existing half-cent transportation sales tax for forty years
Facebook is founded

BNSF is the major carrier in the county and its mainline extends from the border with Orange County down the coast to National City. The port of San Diego is the major freight supplier. In 2004 BNSF moved 2.8 million tons of freight and increase of 23.3 percent over 2003. BNSF also has a branch line between Escondido and Oceanside.
Congress passed the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act, which authorized increased spending adding 10,000 new agents to U.S. Border Patrol
TransNet given 40 year extension
Smart Growth Concept Map revealed
Transet Environmental Mitigation Program

The Safe, Accountable Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users, the Indian Reservation Roads (IRR) program funding formula was revised to allow tribes to include off-reservation transportation facilities critical to reservations as part of their tribal transportation system.
Southern California Tribal Chairmen's Association (SCTCA) becomes Advisory Member to the Borders Committee
SB 18 require cities and counties to consult with tribal nations when conducting any element of the general plan
The Independent Taxpayer Oversight Committee (ITOC) is formed in accordance with TransNet ordinance to monitor program operations.
Jerry Sanders elected Mayor of CIty of San Diego
Angela Merkel becomes Germany's first woman Chancellor.
Hurricane Katrina strikes the gulf states.
SDIA handled more than 167,000 tons (air cargo)
Environmental Mitigation Program Working Group Established
Otay Ranch Shopping Center opens.

The Safe, Accountable Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users, the Indian Reservation Roads (IRR) program funding formula was revised to allow tribes to include off-reservation transportation facilities critical to reservations as part of their tribal transportation system.
San Diego Regional Tribal Summit hosted by the Pala Band of Mission Indians
Interagency Technical Working Group on Tribal Transportation formed to facilitate exchange between tribal nations and public agencies. 14 of the 17 tribes in the region are members of the group.
Intertribal Court of Southern California begins operations.
Twitter is founded.
approximately $29.8 billion in trade was handled by the Otay Mesa and Tecate POEs in San Diego County
SANDAG completes the "Economic Impacts of Wait Times at the San Diego–Baja California Border" study, which was the first to quantify the economic impacts of delays experienced at the border.
Sand Compatibility and Opportunistic Use Program
Series 11: 2030 Regional Growth Forecast Update - Historical Projection
The campus successfully concludes The Campaign for UC San Diego, a seven-year initiative that raises more than $1.01 billion in private support from over 100,000 individuals and organizations.
Sharp Memorial Hospital and San Diego Cardiac Center participate in the first-ever human gene transfer therapy clinical trial in patients with heart failure.
Scripps Mercy Hospital acquires da Vinci, an advanced robotic surgery system that can make many surgeries less invasive

The Safe, Accountable Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users, the Indian Reservation Roads (IRR) program funding formula was revised to allow tribes to include off-reservation transportation facilities critical to reservations as part of their tribal transportation system.
2007 Poomacha Fire destroyed 99% of the La Jolla band of Luseño reservation.
SANDAG and the Southern California Tribal Chairmen's Association signed MOU for representation on Board and Policy Advisory Committees

Tribal Transit Feasibility Study was conducted after Caltrans gave San Diego a technical grant. The study analyze connections between transit district and travel reservations. The study lead to improvements to I-15 to SR 76 and bus route improvement through a Reservation Transportation Authority grant
Intertribal Long-Term Recovery Foundation is formed after wildfires of 2007. The foundation addresses long-term recovery for Native American needs in relation to natural disasters
Southern California Tribal Chairman's Association joins SANDAG as advisory member.
Steve jobs unveils the iPhone
SANDAG awarded $432 million in state infrastructure bond dollars for transportation improvements.
SANDAG and the City of Tijuana approve the Otay Mesa-Mesa de Otay Binational Corridor Strategic Plan.
The Imperial Valley Association of Governments completes the "Imperial Valley-Mexicali Economic Delay Study", which quantified impacts of delays experienced at the POEs in Imperial County.
San Diego Regional Beach Sand Replenismnet Project Feasibility Study
Coastal Regional Sediment Management Program

Roger Tsien, PhD, professor of pharmacology, chemistry and biochemistry at UC San Diego School of Medicine, shares the Nobel Prize in chemistry for his work with glowing proteins, now being used as a surgical aid.

The Safe, Accountable Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users, the Indian Reservation Roads (IRR) program funding formula was revised to allow tribes to include off-reservation transportation facilities critical to reservations as part of their tribal transportation system.
Tribal Transportation Feasibility Study conduct to understand the connections between the tribal reservations and the transit system
San Diego County records highest ever voter turnout in presidential general election
San Diegan’s vote to ban consuming alcohol at public parks and beaches
Barack Obama is elected as United States first African American President
San Diego Military Advisory Council (SDMAC) begins conducting its Military Economic Impact Study (MEIS)
Global Economic Recesson starts, significantly reducing the number of crossborder trips

In an effort to address organized crime, U.S. and Mexican federal governments sign The Mérida Initiative. This instituted a higher level of binational cooperation and ushered in a "21st-century border" (included funding for border security/communications technology improvements). Later phases added Mexico's southern border as a focus for secirty funding, which impacted the volume of South American immigration.
SANDAG is issued the U.S. Presidential Permit for the Otay Mesa East POE and also recieves Toll Authority through legislation (Senate Bill 1486).
The first stretch of I-15 Express Lanes opens.
East County - Multiple Species Conservation Program

The Safe, Accountable Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users, the Indian Reservation Roads (IRR) program funding formula was revised to allow tribes to include off-reservation transportation facilities critical to reservations as part of their tribal transportation system.
Reservation Transportation Authority awarded Tribal Transit Grant to supplement North County Transit District route 388/389
Burj Khalifa in Dubai, the world's tallest skyscraper, is completed.
the Water Authority played a key role in helping pass a historic legislative package designed to make long-term improvements in statewide water management and water supply reliability.

The Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative (WHTI) requires that all travelers entering the country, foreigners and U.S. citizens alike, must present a passport or other accepted document to prove their nationality and identity
Launched SuperLoop service in University City.
Regional Alternative Fuels, Vehicles, and Infrastructure Report (SANDAG)
Regional Energy Strategy (SANDAG)
SANDAG and partner agencies acquired nine properties totaling nearly 1,000 acres for habitat conservation through TransNet Environmental Mitigation Program.
San Diego Regional Tribal Summit hosted by the Rincon Band of Luiseno Indians. Emphasis on tribal employment and involvement of tribal nations and influence of tribal transportation projects
Creation of Office of the Tribal Advisor through Exec Order B-10-11 which emphasized the importance of tribal-state relations
Matt Hall elected Mayor of Carlsbad
Dilma Rousseff is elected as the first female president of Brazil.
SANDAG completes the "San Diego and Imperial County Freight Gateway Study", which became a key resource for planning around the dynamics of frieght movements throughout the border region.
SR 905 is converted to a full freeway and a portion is opened to the public
SANDAG announces 2050 Regional Bike Plan
Compass Card program rolled out to all transit riders; monthly paper passes discontinued.
Climate Action Strategy (SANDAG)
Energy Roadmap Program
Series 12: 2050 Regional Growth Forecast - Historical Projection
2050 RTP has a tribal component in the Project Evaluation and Performance Measures criteria
Arab Spring: revolutions in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya follow, as well as uprisings in Yemen and Bahrain, and protests in several other Arab countries.
Navy Broadway Complex Redevelopment Project

Memorandum of Understanding is signed between key Otay Mesa East Port of Entry project partners (U.S. General Services Administration, U.S. CBP, U.S. Federal Highways Administration, Caltrans and SANDAG)
SR 52 opens in March
Sustainable Communities Strategy (SCS). First in the state
Conservation and Open Space Element (County)
Military begins pacific pivot

The Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st-Century Act, removed the provision that allowed tribes to include all preservation transportation facilities. This strips tribal resources to plan for mobility and transportation. See "2005-2009" for the original laws that were changed
Helping Expedite and Avance Responsible Tribal Homeownership Act is passed. This helps conduct home ownership on tribal lands
AB 307 goes into effect. It creates a state and local mechanism for federally recognized tribes to be considered public agencies and entered joint power agreements (JPA).
VIejas enters JPA with Heartland Fire Authority
Skydiver Felix Baumgartner becomes the first person to break the sound barrier without a vehicle.
SR 905 opened to traffic, providing access to Otay Mesa Port of Entry
Dole extends
All roadway segments of SR 905 finish construction, connecting the border areas of San Ysidro and Otay Mesa to the I-5 and I-805 corridors
California Transportation Commission approves the implementation of State Route 11
Opened the last four miles of the I-15 Express Lanes.
Daimler launched the first all electric free-float carshare program in SD
Buena Vista Lagoon Enhancement Prokect
Regional Beach Sand Project
The Headquarters opens in former San Diego Police Headquarters
Pope Benedict XVI resigns and Pope Francis becomes Pope.
Forbes ranks San Diego among nation’s top 10 cities with greenest cars
The western portion of the Las Americas Premium Outlets opens in San Ysidro
Purchase of Agricultural Conservation Easement (PACE) Program (County)
Series 13: 2050 Regional Growth Forecast
Holiday Bowl begins hosting power 5 conference teams

The J. Craig Venter Institute—a $37 million research facility—is launched by alumnus J. Craig Venter. Researchers focus on everything from continued sequencing and analysis of the human genome, to new research in synthetic biology and cataloging and sequencing of the vast unseen life in the world’s oceans, rivers and soils.
California Department of Public Health designates the five UC medical centers as the state's primary Ebola treatment centers.
San Diego Regional Tribal Summit hosted by the Barona Band of Mission Indians
Bill Wells elected Mayor of El Cajon
Mark Arapostathis elected Mayor of La Mesa
Steve Vaus elected Mayor of Poway
Kevin Faulconer elected Mayor of City of San Diego
Serge Dedina elected Mayor of Imperial Beach
Mary Salas elected Mayor of Chula Vista
The Rosetta spacecraft's Philae probe becomes the first to successfully land on a comet.

SPAWAR has nearly 10,000 employees, and close to 5,000 of them work in San Diego developing the hardware and software that keeps naval forces connected. The business pumps more than $1.7 billion into the San Diego economy.
SDG&E territory reached 10,000 electric vehicles on the road - California hit 100,000 mark
Began construction to expand the San Ysidro Freight Rail Yard – an important project to expedite loading between freight cars and trucks.
The eastern portion of the Las Americas Premium Outlets opens in San Ysidro
MOU signed between the State of California and the Mexican federal government, forming a binational oversight committee to expedite the OME project
President Barack Obama announced an executive action on immigration reform, which granted temporary work permits and indefinite deportation exemptions to four million undocumented immigrants
Launched Rapid services along the I-15 corridor and in the Mid-City area, including Rapid 215, Rapid 235, and Rapid 237, and began construction on Downtown San Diego Rapid stations.
Sustainable Communities Strategy (SCS)
Kaaboo Music and Arts Festival holds inaugural show in del mar
Federal legislation requires that federally recognized tribal governments be consulted in the development of Regional Transportation Plans (RTP) and programs
Fixing America's Surface Transportation (FAST) Act is passed and reinforces federal emphasis on tribal gov participation

San Diego Forward: The Regional Plan (2015 Regional Plan) and Sustainable Communities Strategy 2015 is approved. The RP focuses on transportation improvements in urban areas but most tribes live in rural areas. SANDAG plans on working with different stakeholders including tribal nations.
Liquid water is found on Mars.

the Water Authority helped develop the nation's largest seawater desalination plant, the Claude "Bud" Lewis Carlsbad Desalination Plant. Commercial water production at the plant started in December 2015, and it produces approximately 50 million gallons of high-quality drinking water each day, further protecting the San Diego region from water supply shortages.

The Cross Border Xpress (CBX) facility opens to the public in December 2015, marking a milestone in binational collaboration and providing a direct connection between the U.S. (via the Otay Mesa area) and the Tijuana International Airport in Mexico.
Completed renovation of Trolley Blue Line stations from Barrio Logan to San Ysidro and added 65 new low-floor vehicles to the Orange and Blue Trolley Lines as part of the Trolley Renewal Project.
Completed construction on a .6-mile extension of the Bayshore Bikeway along Harbor Drive between 32nd Street and Vesta Street.
MLB sends All Star Week to Petco Park
AB 52 establishes "Tribal Cultural Resources" category which requires consideration of tribal cultural value, scientific value, archaeological value
Sustainable Groundwater Management Plans and strategies implemented. Many tribes participated as they sit on watersheds
John Minto elected Mayor of Santee
Raquel Vasquez elected Mayor of Lemon Grove and the first African American woman to be elected mayor in San Diego county
San Diegan’s vote no on proposed hotel tax to fund home stadium for San Diego Chargers
Catherine Blakespear elected Mayor of Encinitas
Richard Bailey elected Mayor of Coronado
Detection of gravitational waves by LIGO confirmed.
An estimated total of $23 billion in direct spending related to defense was sent to San Diego County during fiscal year 2016, an amount equal to more than $7,000 for each of the county's residents.

UC San Diego Health surgeons perform the region's first heart-liver transplant. The academic medical center is the only local hospital to perform heart-lung, living-donor liver, and multi-organ chest-abdominal transplants.

the Port established a Blue Economy Incubator Program to assist in the creation, development, and scaling of new business ventures on San Diego Bay, focusing on aquaculture, or the cultivation of aquatic plants and rearing of aquatic animals for food; and on Blue Tech, particularly the research and development of technology for sustainable ocean use.
SY Freight Rail Yard and South Line Freight Rail Capacity projects

SANDAG and Caltrans open the first segment of State Route 11 to traffic, which provides access to the future OME POE. Key freeway connectors are also opened to traffic, linking SR 11 to the SR 905 and SR 125.
Mid Coast Trolley construction begins
Opened Segment 1 of the SR 11/Otay Mesa East Port of Entry Project, a brand new freeway in Otay Mesa, near the U.S.-Mexico border.

Completed the I-805 North Project, which created two carpool lanes between SR 52 and Mira Mesa Boulevard. The project also included a direct access ramp (DAR) at Carroll Canyon Road, which enables carpools, buses, and other eligible vehicles to go straight into the High-Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes.
Waste Management Plan for Alexan - Fashion Valley Project

As of December 2016, the TransNet Environmental Mitigation Grant Program has helped SANDAG acquire more than 8,600 acres of sensitive habitat in partnership with other organizations and conservation groups.
Sally Roush first woman to be named president of SDSU

Tribal Consulation Plan approved by SCTCA and BOD board. Elements include leadership meetings between SANDAG and the SCTCA, policy listening sessions, a Tribal Transportation Working Group, a Tribal Summit, and collaboration in the 2019 Regional Plan.

Tribal Consulation Plan approved by SCTCA and BOD board. Elements include leadership meetings between SANDAG and the SCTCA, policy listening sessions, a Tribal Transportation Working Group, a Tribal Summit, and collaboration in the 2019 Regional Plan.
Britain triggers Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, official beginning the process known as Brexit.
SANDAG and Armed Forces MOA revised appointing Civilian CEO of Navy Region Southwest on Board and San Diego Regional Military Working Group

The Port has two marine cargo terminals, Tenth Avenue and National City, which processed over 1.8 million tons of cargo in 2017 including automobiles, agricultural commodities, lumber, and wind energy components.
Cruise ship terminals that are enjoying increased activity, with 88 cruise calls in 2017, up over 14 percent since 2015
Caltrans and SANDAG began pilot program to test technology which uses Wi-Fi detection equipment to measure border wait times.
Completed $28.1 million in improvements to the Oceanside Transit Center, which made the station more efficient by adding a third track and an additional platform.
Waster Managemet Plan, 5 Year Review (county)
Management and Monitoring Strategic Plan for Conserved Lands in Western San Diego County: A Strategic Habitat Conservation Roadmap

UC San Diego is named the top public university in the nation for social mobility by Washington Monthly. One-third of the incoming 2018 class is the first in their family to attend a four-year college and 40 percent come from low-income households.
The Koman Family Outpatient Pavilion opens to patient care in March, 2018.
Intraregional Tribal Transportation Strategy developed as Early Action from 2015 Regional Plan
San Diego Regional Tribal Summit hosted by the Pala Band of Mission Indians. This is the first time tribes discussed "Emergency Preparedness and Management" in detail
Approved the formation of a Regional Housing Needs Assessment (RHNA) Subcommittee to provide input and guidance during the development of the RHNA Plan.

Began recruitment for a SANDAG Independent Performance Auditor, who will report directly to the Board and Audit Committee and oversee and conduct independent examinations of SANDAG program, functions, and operations.
San Diegan’s vote to use the land currently occupied by SDCCU Stadium for SDSU extended facilities
Alejandra Sotelo-Solis elected Mayor of National City
Judy Ritter elected Mayor of Vista
Rebecca Jones elected Mayor of San Marcos
Paul McNamara elected Mayor of Escondido

SANDAG’s binational partnership with the Mexican government was reinforced with the historic first visit of Honorable Luis Videgaray, the Secretary of Foreign Affairs of Mexico to a Board of Directors meeting.
Prince Harry marries American Megan Markle
Port of San Diego has secured a nearly $5 million grant for the installation of a renewable, solar-powered microgrid at the Tenth Avenue Marine Terminal, one of the Port’s two marine cargo terminals.
Real Estate brokers, agents, and manager account for over 4,000 jobs in San Diego County
more than 10,000 individuals employed in an insurance industry
Business and Financial Operations occupations account for more than 92,000 jobs in San Diego County
U.S. Presidential Permit authorizing the construction of the OME border crossing is renewed

The Secretary of Foreign Affairs of Mexico, Luis Videgaray, makes a historic first visit to SANDAG, underscoring the significance of binational and regional collaboration as well as the importance of the SR 11/ Otay Mesa East Port of Entry project.
dockless mobility exploded in San Diego

San Diego Forward: The 2019-2050 Regional Plan is a planning effort that will combine an overall vision for the region's future. SANDAG plans on working with different stakeholders including tribal nations. Some of the goals of the region's tribes in accordance with the plan is to involve the tribes, improve tribal transportation and funding efforts to tribal lands, and information sharing/technical assistance.
Ellie Haviland elected Mayor of Del Mar
The Event Horizon Telescope takes the first ever image of a black hole, at the core of the galaxy M87.
The San Diego region ranked #2 in the nation in solar installations.

The San Diego Ocean Planning Partnership has released an interactive, user-friendly Web Mapping Application that is designed to help users better understand the dynamic ocean space and ocean-related data offshore San Diego County.
SR 11: construction started on the last segments of the highway

Major industrial users including shipbuilding and boat building and repair facilities such as National Steel and Shipbuilding Company, BAE Systems Ship Repair, Huntington Ingalls Industries, and Marine Group Boat Works
All right-of-way is secured for the site of the future OME POE, as well as remainder of needed right-of-way for SR 11
The Governors of California, Baja California and Baja California Sur announce the reactivation of the Commission of Las Californias.
Launched South Bay Rapid Service between the Otay Mesa Transit Center (at the Otay Mesa international border crossing), the communities of eastern Chula Vista, and downtown San Diego.
Climate Action Plan (City of San Diego)
NAVWAR Redevelopment Exclusivity Agreement

The new United States, Mexico, and Canada Free Trade Agreement (USMCA) is signed by President Trump after several iterations. The agreement is not in effect as it is pending congressional ratification from Canada.

The new United States, Mexico, and Canada Free Trade Agreement (USMCA) is signed by President Donald Trump after several iterations. The agreement is not in affect as it is pending full congretional ratification from Canada.
Local Native Americans become skilled horsemen and fur traders. They provide the labor force for the first Spanish led communities.
Independent Kumeyaay warriors begin to dominate most of inland San Diego County
Local Native Americans work as tradesmen work in coastal communities, some take crewmen positions on whaling ships
Local Native Americans provide domestic and day labor for the building of initial San Diego infrastructure.
Treaty lands, pueblos lands and water sources are taken or diverted from the Local Native Americans to supply the growing coastal population
Railroad and Real Estate speculators combine with city boosters to create a glamorized portrayal of California history and the missions
Local Native Americans provide the labor for the first highways, telegraph and railroad through the eastern mountains and desert
Native Americans become the backbone of the first migratory crop pickers in California
Mexico became SANDAG Advisory Board Member (then City of San Diego Councilmember Jim Bates led this initiative)
Regional Beach Monitoring Program Annual Report and Appendixes
North County - Multiple Species Conservation Program Development Starter
Quino Butterfly Addition to South County MSCP
Over millenia, local Native Americans establish a rich, productive balance with the local natural resources; sufficient for a population in the tens of thousands.
Local Native Americans harvest the sea, manage the chaparral and learn to utilize the deserts of Imperial Valley
Local Native Americanschart the sky as astronomers, master the botanical characteristics of local plants, create and enhance water storage in wetlands.
Archeological evidence shows at least 12,000 years of habitation in San Diego County, including the border region. Kumeyaay inhabit the land that will become the cities of San Diego and Tijuana.
The four ethnic groups that have lived in the San Diego region are: Kumeyaay, Cupeño, Cahuilla, Luseño

Archeological evidence shows at least 10,000 years of habitation in San Diego County, including the border region. Native tribes including the Pai Pai, Cucupa, and the Kumeyaay inhabit the land that will become San Diego and Tijuana.
